ImageData.LabelName: Nonmelanoma Skin Cancer of the Head and Neck (Carcinoma in situ)

OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Revision: Added a second line pointing to another cell for the Abnormal squamous cells label; made Normal basal cells plural and added a second line pointing to another cell
Changed title to â€œNonmelanoma Skin Cancer of the Head and Neck (Carcinoma in situ)"

Added abnormal squamous cells and abnormal basal cells to the epidermis; added two separate corresponding inset boxes, one showing the normal/abnormal basal cells in more detail and one showing the normal/abnormal squamous cells in more detail; and removed the big lesions from the top of the skin

Added another inset box so that the normal/abnormal basal cells are in one and the normal/abnormal squamous cells are in the other; and made two different areas on the main skin figure squamous cell cancer and basal cell cancer
Smoothed out lesion a bit to make it a little less angry looking

Made a little more contrast between the area with the abnormal cells and the rest of the epidermis; moved the hair follicle over and faded out all of the structures except the epidermis; labeled Abnormal basal cells and Abnormal squamous cells in the inset
Image revisions made per AJCC 8th edition updates
Changed title to uppercase N in Stage 0 Nonmelanoma

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Nonmelanoma skin cancer of the head and neck (carcinoma in situ); drawing shows abnormal squamous cells and basal cells in the epidermis. Also shown are the dermis and the subcutaneous tissue below the dermis. There are two insets: the inset on the left shows a close up of normal and abnormal squamous cells; the inset on the right shows a close up of normal and abnormal basal cells.

Nonmelanoma skin cancer of the head and neck (carcinoma in situ); drawing shows abnormal squamous cells and basal cells in the epidermis. Also shown are the dermis and the subcutaneous tissue below the dermis. There are two insets: the inset on the left shows a close up of normal and abnormal squamous cells; the inset on the right shows a close up of normal and abnormal basal cells.

Captions.MediaCaption: Nonmelanoma skin cancer of the head and neck (carcinoma in situ). Abnormal cells are found in the squamous cell or basal cell layer of the epidermis. These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.

Nonmelanoma skin cancer of the head and neck (carcinoma in situ). Abnormal cells are found in the squamous cell or basal cell layer of the epidermis. These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.

ProposedUse.Glossary: stage 0 nonmelanoma skin carcinoma in situ on the head and neck (not on the eyelid)
nonmelanoma skin carcinoma in situ on the head and neck (not on the eyelid)
